[[File:Chaman amazonie 5 06.jpg|thumb|250px|right|A [[shaman]] from the [[Amazon Rainforest]]: the health management system uses information about being treated from healers to limit the deployment of the body's own evolved self-treatments such as [[fever]], [[sickness behavior]], and [[pain]].]] The '''health management system''' (HMS) is an [[evolutionary medicine]] regulative process proposed by [[Nicholas Humphrey]]{{cite book |author=Humphrey, Nicholas |chapter=19. Great Expectations: The Evolutionary Psychology of Faith-Healing and the Placebo Effect |chapterurl=http://www.humphrey.org.uk/papers/2002GreatExpectations.pdf |title=The Mind Made Flesh: Essays from the Frontiers of Psychology and Evolution |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford [Oxfordshire] |year=2002 |pages=255–85 |isbn=0-19-280227-5 }} reprinted from {{cite book |author=Hofsten, Claes von |title=Psychology at the Turn of the Millennium: Social, Developmental and Clinical Perspectives |publisher=Psychology Press |location=East Sussex |year=2002 |pages=225–46 |isbn=1-84169-199-2 |volume=2}} {{cite book |author=Humphrey, Nicholas |chapter=The Placebo Effect |editor=Gregory, Richard Langton |authorlink=Richard Gregory |title=The Oxford companion to the mind |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford [Oxfordshire] |year=2004 |isbn=0-19-866224-6 |edition=2nd}} in which actuarial assessment of [[Biological fitness|fitness]] and economic-type [[cost–benefit analysis]] determines the body’s regulation of its [[physiology]] and [[health]]. This incorporation of cost–benefit calculations into body regulation provides a science grounded approach to [[Mind-body connection|mind–body]] phenomena such as [[placebos]] that are otherwise not explainable by low level, noneconomic, and purely feedback based [[homeostasis|homeostatic]] or [[allostasis|allostatic]] theories. * Many medical [[symptoms]] such as [[inflammation]], [[fever]], pain, [[sickness behavior]], or [[morning sickness]] have an [[evolutionary medicine]] function of enabling the body to protect, heal or restore itself from [[injury]], [[infection]] or other physiological disruption. * The deployment of self-treatments have [[Deployment cost–benefit selection in physiology|costs]] as well as benefits with the result that evolution has selected management processes in the brain such that self-treatments are used only when they provide an overall [[cost–benefit]] advantage. The brain controls such physiological process through [[Neural top–down control of physiology|top–down regulation]]. * External treatment and the availability of support is factored into the health management system’s cost–benefit assessment as to whether to deploy or not an evolved self-treatment. [[Placebos]] are explained as the result of false information about the availability of external treatment and support that mislead the health management system {{cite web |authors=Selvanski Monsu |title=Healthcare Management Systems |date=December 2012 |url=http://www.nintec.com/healthcare}} into not deploying evolved self-treatments. This results in the placebo suppression of medical symptoms. ==Evolutionary medicine== Since [[Hippocrates]], it has been recognized that the body has self-healing powers ([[vis medicatrix naturae]]). Modern [[evolutionary medicine]] identifies them with physiologically based self-treatments that provide the body with [[prophylactic]], healing, or restorative capabilities against injuries, infections and physiological disruption. Examples include: * [[Immunity (medical)|Immune responses]] * [[Fever]] * [[Sickness behavior]] * [[Nausea]] * [[Morning sickness]] * [[Diarrhea]] * [[Iron deficiency (medicine)|Hypoferremia]] * [[Major depressive disorder|Depression]] * [[pain#Evolutionary and behavioral role|Pain]] These evolved self-treatments deployed by the body are experienced by humans as unpleasant and unwanted illness [[symptoms]]. ==Deployment== Such self-treatments according to evolutionary medicine are deployed to increase an individual’s [[biological fitness]]. Two factors affect their deployment. First, it is usually advantageous to deploy them on a [[precautionary principle|precautionary basis]].{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.2001.tb03472.x |author=Nesse RM |authorlink=Randolph M. Nesse |title=The smoke detector principle. Natural selection and the regulation of defensive responses |journal=Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. |volume=935 |issue= |pages=75–85 |date=May 2001 |pmid=11411177 |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/resolve/openurl?genre=article&sid=nlm:pubmed&issn=0077-8923&date=2001&volume=935&spage=75}} As a result, it will often turn out that they have been deployed apparently unnecessarily, though this has in fact been advantageous since in probabilistic terms they have provided an insurance against a potentially costly outcome. As Nesse notes: "Vomiting, for example, may cost only a few hundred calories and a few minutes, whereas not vomiting may result in a 5% chance of death" page 77. Second, self-treatments are costly both in using energy, and also in their risk of damaging the body. * Immunity – energy for activating lymphocyte and antibody production,{{cite journal |vauthors=Lochmiller R, Deerenberg C |title=Trade-offs in evolutionary immunology: just what is the cost of immunity? |journal=Oikos |volume=88 |issue= |pages=87–98 |year=2000 |doi=10.1034/j.1600-0706.2000.880110.x }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Romanyukha AA, Rudnev SG, Sidorov IA |title=Energy cost of infection burden: an approach to understanding the dynamics of host-pathogen interactions |journal=J. Theor. Biol. |volume=241 |issue=1 |pages=1–13 |date=July 2006 |pmid=16378624 |doi=10.1016/j.jtbi.2005.11.004 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0022-5193(05)00479-0}} and in the risk of an immune response resulting in an [[immune disorders|immune related disorder]]. * Fever – energy (each 1 °C raise in blood temperature increases energy expenditure by 10–15%.{{cite journal |vauthors=Rodriguez DJ, Sandoval W, Clevenger FW |title=Is measured energy expenditure correlated to injury severity score in major trauma patients? |journal=J. Surg. Res. |volume=59 |issue=4 |pages=455–9 |date=October 1995 |pmid=7564317 |doi=10.1006/jsre.1995.1191 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0022-4804(85)71191-2}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1097/00000658-196501000-00022 |vauthors=Roe CF, Kinney JM |title=The Caloric Equivalent of Fever II. Influence of Major Trauma |journal=Ann. Surg. |volume=161 |issue= 1|pages=140–7 |date=January 1965 |pmid=14252624 |pmc=1408758 }} 90% of the total cost of fighting [[pneumonia]] goes on increased body temperature. There is also the risk of [[hyperpyrexia]]. * Sickness behavior – restricted ability by an animal to forage and defend itself * Nausea – loss of food nutrients, and potential risk of [[Vomiting#Complications|aspiration]] * Morning sickness – loss of food nutrients when a mother needs additional, not less, nourishment * Hypoferremia – impairment in biological processes needing iron resulting in [[iron deficiency anemia]] * Depression – [[Evolutionary approaches to depression|impaired activity and problem solving]]. * Pain – restricted movement and the [[Chronic pain#Related sequelae|inability to concentrate]] One factor in deployment is low level physiological control by [[proinflammatory cytokine]]s such as [[Interleukin 1|IL-1]] triggered by bacterial [[lipopolysaccharides]] (LPS). Another is [[Neural top down control of physiology|higher level control]] in which the brain takes into account what it learns about circumstances and how that makes it well and ill. [[Classical conditioning|Conditioning]] shows the existence of such learnt control: give saccharin paired in a drink with a drug that creates [[immunosuppression]], and later on, giving saccharin alone will produce immunosuppression.{{cite journal |vauthors=Ader R, Cohen N |title=Behaviorally conditioned immunosuppression |journal=Psychosom Med |volume=37 |issue=4 |pages=333–40 |year=1975 |pmid=1162023 |url=http://www.psychosomaticmedicine.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=1162023 |doi=10.1097/00006842-197507000-00007}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1006/nlme.1995.1048 |vauthors=Alvarez-Borda B, Ramírez-Amaya V, Pérez-Montfort R, Bermúdez-Rattoni F |title=Enhancement of antibody production by a learning paradigm |journal=Neurobiol Learn Mem |volume=64 |issue=2 |pages=103–5 |date=September 1995 |pmid=7582817 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1074742785710489}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0889-1591(02)00031-4 |vauthors=Oberbeck R, Kromm A, Exton MS, Schade U, Schedlowski M |title=Pavlovian conditioning of endotoxin-tolerance in rats |journal=Brain Behav. Immun. |volume=17 |issue=1 |pages=20–7 |date=February 2003 |pmid=12615046 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0889159102000314}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Pacheco-López G, Niemi MB, Kou W, etal |title=Behavioural endocrine immune-conditioned response is induced by taste and superantigen pairing |journal=Neuroscience |volume=129 |issue=3 |pages=555–62 |year=2004 |pmid=15541877 |doi=10.1016/j.neuroscience.2004.08.033 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0306-4522(04)00774-2}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0165-5728(98)00011-3 |vauthors=von Hörsten S, Exton MS, Schult M, etal |title=Behaviorally conditioned effects of Cyclosporine A on the immune system of rats: specific alterations of blood leukocyte numbers and decrease of granulocyte function |journal=J. Neuroimmunol. |volume=85 |issue=2 |pages=193–201 |date=May 1998 |pmid=9630168 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0165-5728(98)00011-3}} Such conditioning happens both in experimental rodents and humans.{{cite journal |vauthors=Goebel MU, Trebst AE, Steiner J, etal |title=Behavioral conditioning of immunosuppression is possible in humans |journal=FASEB J. |volume=16 |issue=14 |pages=1869–73 |date=December 2002 |pmid=12468450 |doi=10.1096/fj.02-0389com |url=http://www.fasebj.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12468450}} ==Cost benefit analysis== === Economic resource management=== Evolution, according to [[Nicholas Humphrey]], has selected an internal health management system that uses [[cost benefit analysis]] upon whether the deployment of a self-treatment aids [[biological fitness]], and so should be activated.
a specially designed procedure for “economic resource management” that is, I believe, one of the key features of the “natural health-care service” which has evolved in ourselves and other animals to help us deal throughout our lives with repeated bouts of sickness, injury, and other threats to our well-being.
An analogy is explicitly made with the [[health economics]] consideration used in management decisions involving external medical treatment.
Now, if you wonder about this choice of managerial terminology for talking about biological healing systems, I should say that it is quite deliberate (and so is the pun on NHS.) With the phrase “natural health-care service” I do intend to evoke, at a biological level, all the economic connotations that are so much a part of modern health-care in society.
===External medications=== External medications will affect the cost benefits advantages of deploying an evolved self-treatment. Some animals use [[Zoopharmacognosy|external ones]].{{cite book |author=Engel, Cindy |title=Wild Health : Lessons in Natural Wellness from the Animal Kingdom |publisher=Houghton Mifflin |location=Boston |year=2003 |pages= |isbn=0-618-34068-8 }} [[wildlife|Wild animals]], including [[apes]], do so in the form of ingested [[geophagy|detoxifying clays]],{{cite journal |vauthors=Klein N, Fröhlich F, Krief S |title=Geophagy: soil consumption enhances the bioactivities of plants eaten by chimpanzees |journal=Naturwissenschaften |volume=95 |issue=4 |pages=325–31 |date=April 2008 |pmid=18188538 |doi=10.1007/s00114-007-0333-0}} rough leaves that clear gut parasites,{{cite journal |vauthors=Fowler A, Koutsioni Y, Sommer V |title=Leaf-swallowing in Nigerian chimpanzees: evidence for assumed self-medication |journal=Primates |volume=48 |issue=1 |pages=73–6 |date=January 2007 |pmid=16897194 |doi=10.1007/s10329-006-0001-6}} and pharmacologically active plants{{cite journal |doi=10.1079/PNS2003257 |author=Huffman MA |title=Animal self-medication and ethno-medicine: exploration and exploitation of the medicinal properties of plants |journal=Proc Nutr Soc |volume=62 |issue=2 |pages=371–81 |date=May 2003 |pmid=14506884 }}{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0031-9384(94)90368-9 |vauthors=Koshimizu K, Ohigashi H, Huffman MA |title=Use of Vernonia amygdalina by wild chimpanzee: possible roles of its bitter and related constituents |journal=Physiol. Behav. |volume=56 |issue=6 |pages=1209–16 |date=December 1994 |pmid=7878093 }} Complementary to this, research finds that animals have the ability to select and prefer substances that aid their recuperation from illness.{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.173.3998.749 |vauthors=Green KF, Garcia J |title=Recuperation from illness: flavor enhancement for rats |journal=Science |volume=173 |issue=3998 |pages=749–51 |date=August 1971 |pmid=5568508 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=5568508}} ===Social support=== The welfare of social animals (including humans) depends upon other individuals ([[Tend and befriend|social buffering]]).{{cite journal |vauthors=Kikusui T, Winslow JT, Mori Y |title=Social buffering: relief from stress and anxiety |journal=Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Lond. B Biol. Sci. |volume=361 |issue=1476 |pages=2215–28 |date=December 2006 |pmid=17118934 |pmc=1764848 |doi=10.1098/rstb.2006.1941 |url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17118934}} The actuarial assessments of the costs and benefits of deploying a self-treatment therefore will depend upon the presence, or not, of other individuals. The presence of helpful others will affect, for example, the risk of predators when incapacitated, and—in those case in which animals do this (such as humans)—the provision of food, and care during sickness. The health management system factors in the presence of such external treatment and social support as one aspect of the circumstances needed to determine whether it is advantageous to deploy or not an evolved self-treatment. ==Placebos== ===False information=== All humans societies use external medications, and some individuals exist that are considered to have special [[healers|healing]] knowledge about illnesses and their treatments. Humans are also usually supportive to those in their group. The availability of these things will affect the cost benefits of the body deploying its own biological ones. This could, in turn, lead to the health management system (given its beliefs (information) about treatments and support) to deploy or not, or doing so differently, the body’s own treatments. Nicholas Humphrey describes how the health management system explains placebos – an external treatment without direct physiological effects – as follows:
Suppose, for example, a doctor gives someone who is suffering an infection a pill that she rightly believes to contain an antibiotic: because her hopes will be raised she will no doubt make appropriate adjustments to her health-management strategy – lowering her precautionary defences in anticipation of the sickness not lasting long.
The health management system, in other words, when faced with an infection is tricked into making a mistaken cost benefit analysis using false information. The effect of that false information is that the benefits of the self-treatment cease to outweigh its costs. As a result, it is not deployed, and an individual does not experience unwanted medical symptoms. ===Lack of harm=== Failure to deploy an evolved self-treatment need not put an individual at risk since evolution has advantaged their deployment on a precautionary basis. As Nicholas Humphrey notes:
many of the health-care measures we’ve been discussing are precautionary measures designed to protect from dangers that lie ahead in an uncertain future. Pain is a way of making sure you give your body rest just in case you need it. Rationing the use of the immune system is a way of making sure you have the resources to cope with renewed attacks just in case they happen. Your healing systems are basically tending to be cautious, and sometimes over-cautious, as if working on the principle of better safe than sorry.
Therefore, not deploying an evolved self-treatment, and so not having a medical symptom due to placebo false information might be without consequence. ==Central governor== The health management system’s idea of a top down neural control of the body is also found in the idea that a [[central governor]] regulates [[muscle weakness|muscle fatigue]] to protect the body from the harmful effects (such as [[Hypoxia (medical)|anoxia]] and [[hyperglycemia]]) of over prolonged exercise. The idea of a fatigue governor was first proposed in 1924 by the 1922 [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Nobel Prize]] winner [[Archibald Hill]],{{cite journal |vauthors=Hill AV, Long CN, Lupton H |title=Muscular exercise, lactic acid and the supply and utilisation of oxygen. Parts I–III |journal=Proc. R. Soc. Lond. |volume=97 |pages=438–75 |year=1924 |url=http://journals.royalsociety.org/content/k51611345m783727/fulltext.pdf }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and more recently, on the basis of modern research, by [[Tim Noakes]].{{cite journal |doi=10.2165/00007256-200333030-00001 |vauthors=St Clair Gibson A, Baden DA, Lambert MI, etal |title=The conscious perception of the sensation of fatigue |journal=Sports Med |volume=33 |issue=3 |pages=167–76 |year=2003 |pmid=12656638 }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Noakes TD, St Clair Gibson A, Lambert EV |title=From catastrophe to complexity: a novel model of integrative central neural regulation of effort and fatigue during exercise in humans: summary and conclusions |journal=Br J Sports Med |volume=39 |issue=2 |pages=120–4 |date=February 2005 |pmid=15665213 |pmc=1725112 |doi=10.1136/bjsm.2003.010330 |url=http://bjsm.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=15665213}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Noakes TD, Peltonen JE, Rusko HK |title=Evidence that a central governor regulates exercise performance during acute hypoxia and hyperoxia |journal=J. Exp. Biol. |volume=204 |issue=Pt 18 |pages=3225–34 |date=September 2001 |pmid=11581338 |url=http://jeb.biologists.org/cgi/reprint/204/18/3225}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1034/j.1600-0838.2000.010003123.x |author=Noakes TD |title=Physiological models to understand exercise fatigue and the adaptations that predict or enhance athletic performance |journal=Scand J Med Sci Sports |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=123–45 |date=June 2000 |pmid=10843507 |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/resolve/openurl?genre=article&sid=nlm:pubmed&issn=0905-7188&date=2000&volume=10&issue=3&spage=123}}{{cite journal |doi=10.2165/00007256-200131090-00001 |vauthors=St Clair Gibson A, Lambert ML, Noakes TD |title=Neural control of force output during maximal and submaximal exercise |journal=Sports Med |volume=31 |issue=9 |pages=637–50 |year=2001 |pmid=11508520 }} Like with the health management system, the central governor shares the idea that much of what is attributed to low level feedback homeostatic regulation is, in fact, due to [[Top-down and bottom-up design|top down]] control by the brain. The advantage of this top down management is that the brain can enhance such regulation by allowing it to be modified by information. For example, in endurance running, a [[Cost-benefit analysis|cost benefit]] trade exists off between the advantages of continuing to run, and the risk if this is too prolonged that it might harm the body. Being able to regulate fatigue in terms of information about the benefits and costs of continued exercise would enhance biological fitness. Low level theories exist that suggest that fatigue is due mechanical failure of the exercising muscles ("peripheral fatigue").{{cite book |author=Edwards RHT |chapter=Biochemical bases for fatigue in exercise performance: catastrophe theory in muscular fatigue |veditors=Knuttgen HG, Vogel JA, Poortmans J |title=Biochemistry of exercise |publisher=Human Kinetics |location=Champaign, IL |year=1983 |isbn=978-0-608-07112-1 |pages=1–28 }} However, such low level theories do not explain why running muscle fatigue is affected by information relevant to cost benefit trade offs. For example, [[marathon]] runners can carry on running longer if told they are near the finishing line, than far away. The existence of a central governor can explain this effect. ==See also== * [[Central governor]] * [[Deployment cost–benefit selection in physiology]] * [[Evolutionary medicine]] * [[Health science]] * [[Management control system]] * [[Mind–body (disambiguation)|Mind–body]] * [[Neural top–down control of physiology]] * [[Placebo effect]] * [[Psychogenic disease]] * [[Psychosomatic medicine]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://richarddawkins.net/article,3484,n,n Richard Dawkins interviews Nicholas Humphrey upon Placebos] [[Category:Decision support systems]] [[Category:Human homeostasis]] [[Category:Mind–body interventions]] [[Category:Physiology]] [[Category:Conceptual systems]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use British English|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = How to Start a Revolution | image = How to Start a Revolution (film) poster.jpeg | alt = Movie poster showing close-up of Gene Sharp's face, with title "How to Start a Revolution", and list of awards. | caption = | director = [[Ruaridh Arrow]] | producer = Richard Shaw;<ref name=productionteam/> Cailean Watt, assistant producer; James Otis, executive producer | writer = Ruaridh Arrow | starring = [[Gene Sharp]], Jamila Raqib, Colonel Robert "Bob" Helvey,<ref name=helveystory/> [[Srđa Popović (activist)|Srđa Popović]], [[Ahmed Maher (youth leader)|Ahmed Maher]], Ausama Monajed | music = | cinematography = [[Philip Bloom (filmmaker)|Philip Bloom]]<ref name=productionteam/> | editing = Mike Crozier,<ref name=productionteam/> Lorrin Braddick | studio = | distributor = [[TVF Media|TVF International]]<ref name=tvfmedia/> | released = {{Film date|2011|9|18|df=y}} | runtime = 85 minutes | country = Scotland | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''How to Start a Revolution''''' is a [[BAFTA]] Award-winning British [[documentary film]] about [[Nobel Peace Prize]] nominee and political theorist [[Gene Sharp]], described as the world's foremost scholar on [[nonviolent revolution]]. The 2011 film describes Sharp's ideas, and their influence on popular uprisings around the world. Screened in cinemas and television in more than 22 countries it became popular among the [[Occupy Wall Street Movement]].<ref>[http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/your-democracy/2013/01/gene-sharp-machiavelli-non-violence ''New Statesman'']</ref>
==Synopsis== Directed by British journalist [[Ruaridh Arrow]] the film follows the use of Gene Sharp's work across revolutionary groups throughout the world. There is particular focus on Sharp's key text ''[[From Dictatorship to Democracy]]''<ref>Gene Sharp (2010), [http://www.aeinstein.org/organizations/org/FDTD.pdf ''From Dictatorship to Democracy'' (full text online)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060209144939/http://www.aeinstein.org/organizations/org/FDTD.pdf |date=9 February 2006 }} (4th ed.). East Boston, NA: [[Albert Einstein Institution]]. {{ISBN|978-1-880813-09-6}}, {{ISBN|1-880813-09-2}}, {{OCLC|706499601}}</ref> which has been translated by democracy activists into more than 30 languages and used in revolutions from Serbia and Ukraine to Egypt and Syria. The film describes how Sharp's 198 methods of nonviolent action have inspired and informed uprisings across the globe.
==Cast== A primary character of the film is [[Gene Sharp]], founder of the [[Albert Einstein Institution]], and a 2009 and 2012 nominee for the [[Nobel Peace Prize]].<ref>Oslo Newsroom (27 February 2012). [http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2012/02/27/former-president-bill-clinton-among-nobel-prize-nominees/ "Former President Bill Clinton among Nobel Prize nominees"]. Reuters. The story states: "[[Kristian Berg Harpviken]], director of the [[Peace Research Institute Oslo|Peace Research Institute of Oslo]] and one of the individuals eligible to nominate candidates, has released a short list of those names he had submitted. It is headed by Gene Sharp, a U.S. writer and philosopher who has long advocated non-violent action for social justice" (accessed 5 March 2012).</ref><ref name=arrow12>{{cite news|first=Ruaridh |last=Arrow |title=Gene Sharp: Author of the nonviolent revolution rulebook |newspaper=[[BBC News]] Middle East |date=21 February 2011 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12522848}} (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref> Sharp has been a scholar on nonviolent action for more than 50 years, and has been called both the "[[Machiavelli]] of nonviolence" and the "[[Clausewitz]] of nonviolent warfare."<ref>{{cite book|last=Weber |first=Thomas |title=Gandhi as Disciple and Mentor |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-521-84230-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P8nC80pG4GIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Gandhi+as+disciple+and+mentor+weber#v=onepage&q&f=false |page=232}}</ref> Other main characters include Jamila Raqib, a former Afghan refugee and the Executive Director of the Albert Einstein Institution;<ref name=siegel11>{{cite news|first=Dan |last=Siegel |title=Film Review: How to Start a Revolution <nowiki>[</nowiki>review of How to Start a Revolution<nowiki>]</nowiki> |newspaper=[[Huffington Post]] |date=19 October 2011 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/dan-siegel/gene-sharp-documentary_b_1018975.html}} (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref> Colonel [[Distinguished Service Cross (United States)|Robert "Bob" Helvey]];<ref name=helveystory>Colonel Robert "Bob" Helvey is a colonel in the United States Army (retired). He served in the Vietnam War, and won a [[Distinguished Service Cross (United States)]], the second highest award for service in the United States military. He is a former executive director of the [[Albert Einstein Institution]], founded by Gene Sharp.</ref> [[Srđa Popović (activist)|Srđa Popović]], leader of [[Otpor!]] students group Serbia;<ref name=holden12>{{cite news|first=Stephen |last=Holden |title=Ways to Change the World, Nonviolently <nowiki>[</nowiki>review of How to Start a Revolution<nowiki>]</nowiki> |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=23 February 2012 |page=C15 |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2012/02/24/movies/gene-sharp-in-documentary-how-to-start-a-revolution.html}}</ref> [[Ahmed Maher (youth leader)|Ahmed Maher]], leader of [[April 6 Youth Movement|April 6 democracy group Egypt]]; and Ausama Monajed, Syrian activist.
==Background and production== Scottish journalist [[Ruaridh Arrow]], who wrote, directed, and co-produced the film, explained that he first learned about Gene Sharp's work as a student, and then heard that Sharp's booklets were turning up on the sites of many revolutions. But Sharp himself remained largely unknown. In explaining his motivation to make the film, Arrow stated that {{Quote|Here was this old man [Gene Sharp] sitting in a crumpled house in Boston and that is where revolutionaries go for advice. It was one of the world's great little secrets. It was a little bit of magic and I had to make a film about it.<ref name=brown12>{{cite news|first=Annie |last=Brown |title=Scot's battle to make film on little-known guru of uprisings around world |newspaper=[[Daily Record (Scotland)]] |date=March 24, 2012 |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/editors-choice/2012/03/24/scot-s-battle-to-make-film-on-little-known-guru-of-uprisings-around-world-86908-23800123/}}</ref>}} The film was privately funded by Ruaridh Arrow and additional funding was raised through the US crowdfunding site [[Kickstarter]].<ref name=brown12/> The film raised $57,342 in just under 4 weeks<ref name=brown12/><ref>Page at Kickstarter for [http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/172444007/how-to-start-a-revolution-a-new-documentary-film How to Start a Revolution]</ref> making it the most successful British crowdfunded film currently completed. Several high-profile figures are credited by the producers with supporting the crowdfunding project, including director [[Richard Linklater]] and actress [[Miriam Margolyes]].<ref>Film website, [http://howtostartarevolutionfilm.com/index.php/credits/thankyou "Special Thanks"] (from howtostartarevolutionfilm.com) (accessed 2 May 2012))</ref> Completion funding was donated by US art collector James Otis who sold the largest collection of [[Gandhi]] possessions including Gandhi's iconic glasses and sandals in 2009. Otis stated that he was selling the items to help fund nonviolent struggle projects and is described as the Executive Producer of the film.<ref>Benjamin Sarlin (1 May 2009). [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2009/03/01/ghandis-few-possessions-go-up-for-auction-in-new-york.html "Gandhi's (Few) Possessions Go Up For Auction in New York"] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref>
Principal photography began in May 2009 with Director of Photography [[Philip Bloom (filmmaker)|Philip Bloom]] in Boston.<ref name=productionteam>[http://howtostartarevolutionfilm.com/index.php/credits/production-team Production Team] (from film website howtostartarevolutionfilm.com) (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref> Interview sequences were shot on Sony EX1 cameras with a Letus 35mm lens adapter and the Canon 5dmk2 DSLR camera.<ref>Philip Bloom website (2011). [http://philipbloom.net/blog/revoultion/ Material about filming Gene Sharp from Blog from 29 May 2009] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref> Ruaridh Arrow travelled to Egypt to film the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|Egyptian revolution]] in February 2011 but his camera equipment was seized by Egyptian secret police on landing and key sequences had to be filmed on the iphone4. Arrow reported live from [[Tahrir Square]] for [[BBC News]] during this period.<ref name=arrow12/>
==Release and accolades== {{Gene Sharp}}The premiere was held in Boston on 18 September 2011, the day after the [[Occupy Wall St]] protests officially began in New York. The film received a standing ovation and won Best Documentary and the Mass Impact award at [[Boston Film Festival]],<ref name=brown12/><ref>{{cite news|first=Will |last=Travers |title=''How to Start a Revolution'' premieres at Boston Film Festival, wins awards |newspaper=Waging Nonviolence |date=27 September 2011 |url=http://wagingnonviolence.org/2011/09/how-to-start-a-revolution-premieres-at-boston-film-festival-wins-awards/}} (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref> and went on to be screened by Occupy camps across the US and Europe including the [[Bank of Ideas]] in London.<ref name=brown12/><ref>Occupy Boston website (9 November 2011) [http://www.occupyboston.org/2011/11/09/how-start-revolution-film-screening-occupy-boston-tonight-7pm/ "“How To Start a Revolution” Film Screening at Occupy Boston tonight, 7pm"] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref><ref>The Occupied Times of London. [http://theoccupiedtimes.co.uk/?p=2289 Sun Street Eviction: No Rescue Package for Bank of Ideas] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref>
The European premiere was held at [[Raindance Film Festival]] in London where the film received the award for Best Documentary.<ref>OneWorld. [http://uk.oneworld.net/article/view/167176/1/ "Revolution at Raindance: Raindance Announces Festival Line Up - The World through a Different Lens"] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref><ref>[http://www.raindance.co.uk/site/nominations-raindance-film-festival-2011 Festival Awards (19th Raindance Festival, October 2011)]</ref> Subsequent awards have included Best Documentary Fort Lauderdale International Film Festival 2011, Special Jury Award One World Film Festival Ottawa, Jury Award Bellingham Human Rights Film Festival and Best Film, Barcelona Human Rights Film Festival. The film won the Scottish [[BAFTA]] for new talent in April 2012 and shortlisted for a [[Grierson Award]] in July 2012.<ref>British Academy of Film and Television Arts, Scotland (12 March 2012). [http://www.bafta.org/scotland/awards/new-talent-awards-nominations-in-2012,3168,BA.html "New Talent Awards Winners in 2012"] (accessed 30 April 2012).</ref>
''How to Start a Revolution'' was picked up for distribution by [[TVF Media|TVF International]]<ref name=tvfmedia>Michael Rosser (11 August 2011) [http://tvfinternational.com/tvf-to-bring-doc-on-non-violent-revolt-to-mipcom/ TVF to bring doc on non-violent revolt to Mipcom] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref> in the UK and 7th Art Releasing in the US.<ref>[http://www.7thart.com/films/How-To-Start-A-Revolution "How to Start a Revolution" (page at Seventh Art Releasing)] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref> The film has reportedly been translated into nine languages, including Japanese and Russian.<ref name=brown12/> The Albert Einstein Institute has reported that the film has been shown internationally on several television stations.<ref>Raqib and Sharp (15 December 2011) [http://www.aeinstein.org/AEI_APPEAL_LETTER_2012.pdf Letter addressed to "Dear Friends"] (posted on website of [[Albert Einstein Institution]]). The letter reported that the film ''How to Start a Revolution'' has been shown "on network television channels in Australia, Israel, and here in the United States on Current Television." (p. 6). (accessed 10 May 2012)</ref>
==Reception== The film has received a positive critical reception. It received four stars in ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]] London'', "a reminder of the importance of intellectual thought to the everyday".<ref>Emmajo Read (no date), [http://admin.timeout.com/film/reviews/91285/how-to-start-a-revolution.html Review of "How to Start a Revolution"], ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]'' (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref> [[The Huffington Post]] said it was a "vital conversation starter and educational tool in a world awash with violence"<ref name=siegel11/> and the UK's [[Daily Telegraph]] described it as a "World conquering Documentary".<ref>{{cite news|first=Louise |last=Gray |title=Gene Sharp: How to Start a Revolution <nowiki>[</nowiki>review of How to Start a Revolution<nowiki>]</nowiki> |newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]] |date=21 October 2011 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmmakersonfilm/8841546/Gene-Sharp-How-to-Start-a-Revolution.html}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]''<ref name=holden12/> called it a "noble documentary" but criticised the absence of historical context of nonviolent struggles pre-dating Sharp. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' described the film as "straightforward", "informative", and "with potential to be updated as world events unfold", stating it "should have a long shelf life". Negative references have been made to the use of dramatic music during certain sequences.<ref>{{cite news|first=Dennis |last=Harvey |title=How to Start a Revolution <nowiki>[</nowiki>film review<nowiki>]</nowiki> |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=1 November 2011 |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117946474/}}</ref>
==Influence== ''How to Start a Revolution'' was released on 18 September 2011 the day after the first Occupy protests in Wall St, New York. The film was described as the unofficial film of the Occupy movement<ref>http://we-make-money-not-art.com/archives/2012/01/the-american-academic-gene-sha.php#.UNSxf0IctUQ</ref> and shown in camps across the US and Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.occupybellinghamwa.org/ai1ec_event/film-how-to-start-a-revolution-at-the-pickford-2/?instance_id%3D |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509115938/http://www.occupybellinghamwa.org/ai1ec_event/film-how-to-start-a-revolution-at-the-pickford-2/?instance_id= |archivedate=9 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://occupymaine.org/voices/25-sun-18-2011-7pm-film-how-to-start-a-revolution |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130222034703/http://occupymaine.org/voices/25-sun-18-2011-7pm-film-how-to-start-a-revolution |archivedate=22 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>http://www.occupyboston.org/2011/11/09/how-start-revolution-film-screening-occupy-boston-tonight-7pm/</ref> It was one of a number of high-profile events held in London's [[Bank of Ideas]] along with a concert by British band [[Radiohead]].{{citation needed|date=January 2013}}
In 2012 following the Mexican general election one of the country's largest newspapers reported that protestors were circulating a pirated Spanish translation of ''How to Start a Revolution'' which had gone viral in the country.<ref>http://www.informador.com.mx/suplementos/2012/422991/6/mr-revolution-y-el-evangelio-de-la-no-violencia.htm</ref> The translation was viewed over half a million times in the space of three days. Reports have also been published citing the airing of the film on Spanish television concurrent with widespread discussion of Sharp's work in the Spanish anti-austerity [[15-M Movement]].<ref>http://wagingnonviolence.org/feature/the-spanish-15-m-movement-deepens-its-civil-disobedience-with-a-dash-of-gene-sharp/</ref>
The academic premiere was hosted by the Program on Negotiation at Harvard Law School on 11 October 2011,<ref>https://www.pon.harvard.edu/students/film-screening-of-how-to-start-a-revolution/?cid=72</ref> and In February 2012, ''How to Start a Revolution'' was screened to an audience of MP's and Lords in the UK [[Houses of Parliament]] by the All Party Parliamentary Group on Conflict Issues (APPGCI) which was attended by Gene Sharp.<ref>http://www.conflictissues.org.uk/index.php/past-meetings-mainmenu-37/126-how-to-start-a-revolution</ref>
A film about the making of ''How to Start a Revolution'', entitled ''Road to Revolution'', was screened in January 2012 by [[Current TV]] in the UK.<ref>[http://current.com/new-year-new-revolution/road-to-revolution Road to Revolution Premieres 1 January at 8.30pm] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref><ref>After the screening of the ''Road to Revolution'', the film itself, ''How to Start a Revolution'', was also shown on [[Current TV]]: [http://current.com/new-year-new-revolution/how-to-start-a-revolution/ ''How To Start A Revolution'' Premieres 1 January at 9pm] (accessed 2 May 2012)</ref>
On January 22, 2017, after the inauguration of President Donald Trump, the [[PBS America]] channel screened ''How to Start a Revolution'' immediately after a ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' investigation into his election.<ref>https://www.pbsamerica.co.uk/series/how-to-start-a-revolution/</ref>
==Touch Documentary== In 2012 ''How to Start a Revolution'' was among the first "[[Touch Documentaries]]" to be released using the Apple iPad platform. The film was integrated into the platform along with four of Gene Sharp's books in several languages, including ''From Dictatorship to Democracy'', and several of Sharp's lectures. The app is supplemented by analysis and satellite mapping which is offered up to the viewer while watching the film.<ref name="internationalpeaceandconflict.org">http://www.internationalpeaceandconflict.org/forum/topics/pcdn-review-of-the-how-to-start-a-revolution-ipad-app?xg_source=activity#.USUXybR2tUQ</ref> A "Revolution Monitor" is also included which fuses Google Earth maps with Twitter displaying tweets and YouTube links from revolutionary groups and individuals when countries of interest are touched by the viewer.<ref>http://howtostartarevolutionfilm.com/index.php/ipad</ref> A review by The Peace & Collaborative Network described the app as "simply a must-have among peace studies scholars, those actively working to start or reorganize revolutions, or anyone who is interested in the logistics, history, and outcomes of nonviolent revolutions" <ref name="internationalpeaceandconflict.org"/> The ''How to Start a Revolution'' [[touch documentary]] was shortlisted for the International Best Digital Media award in the One World Media Awards 2013 <ref>http://oneworldmedia.org.uk/awards/shortlist</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://howtostartarevolution.org/}} * {{IMDb title|1956516|How to Start a Revolution}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = IDRO Group |logo = [[Image:Industrial Development and Renovation Organization of Iran.png|250px]] |type = [[Government-owned corporation]] |foundation = {{start date and age|1967}} |founder = [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]] |location = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] |area_served = [[World]]wide |key_people = [[Mohammadreza Nematzadeh]] ([[Ministry of Industries and Mines (Iran)|Minister of Industry]])
[[Gholamreza Shafeei]] (President)
[[Mansour Mo'azzami]] (Chairman of IDRO Group) |num_employees = |industry = [[Conglomerate (company)|Conglomerate]] |products = [[Automobiles]], [[Vehicles]], [[Engines]], [[Oil]], [[Gas]], [[Energy]], [[Machinery]], [[Agriculture]], [[Mining|Mines]], [[Metals]], [[Research]], [[Training]], [[Aviation]], [[Banking]], [[Trade]], [[Health care]], [[Railway]], [[Management]], [[Technology]], [[Investment]] |revenue = {{increase}}[[United States dollar|US$]] 17 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (2009){{cite web | publisher=Industrial Development and Renovation Organization of Iran (IDRO) | title=Income and Balance Sheets | url=http://www.idro.org/DocLib6/%D8%B5%D9%88%D8%B1%D8%AA%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%8A%20%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%8A%20%D8%AA%D9%84%D9%81%D9%8A%D9%82%D9%8A%205%20%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%87.xls | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321010456/http://www.idro.org/DocLib6/%D8%B5%D9%88%D8%B1%D8%AA%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%8A%20%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%8A%20%D8%AA%D9%84%D9%81%D9%8A%D9%82%D9%8A%205%20%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%87.xls | archivedate=2012-03-21 | df= }} |assets = {{profit}} [[US$]] 45.766 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (2009) |subsid = |net_income = {{increase}}[[US$]] 1.486 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (2009) |homepage = [http://www.idro.org/ www.idro.org] }} The '''Industrial Development & Renovation Organization of Iran''' ('''IDRO''') known as '''IDRO Group''' was established in 1967 in [[Iran]].{{cite web | url= http://www.idro.org/enidro/About%20Idro/History.aspx | title= About IDRO: History | publisher= Industrial Development and Renovation Organization of Iran | accessdate= 2012-01-01 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120419071230/http://www.idro.org/enidro/About%20Idro/History.aspx | archivedate= 2012-04-19 | df= }} IDRO Group is one of the largest companies in [[Iran]]. It is also one of the largest conglomerates in [[Asia]]. IDRO's objective is to develop [[Industry of Iran|Iran's industry sector]] and to accelerate the industrialization process of the country and to export Iranian products worldwide. Today, IDRO owns 117 subsidiaries and affiliated companies both domestically as well as internationally. == Businesses == {{see also|Industry of Iran}} In the course of its 40 years of activity, IDRO has gradually become a major shareholder of some key industries in Iran. In recent years and in accordance with the country's [[Privatization in Iran|privatization]] policy, IDRO has made great efforts to privatize its affiliated companies. While carrying on its privatization policies and lessening its role as a holding company, IDRO intends to concentrate on its prime missions and to turn into an industrial development agency. IDRO has focused its activities on the following areas in order to materialize such strategy and to expedite the [[industrial development]] of Iran: *Promotion of local and [[Foreign Direct Investment in Iran|foreign investments]] with minority holdings owned by IDRO (less than 50% of the shares) with particular emphasis on new, hi-tech and export-oriented industries. *Restructuring the existing industries through participation of reputable foreign companies in order to transfer new technologies and to enhance the [[Iran and International Trade|non-oil exports of Iran]]. *Development of general contracting activities with the participation of the Iranian private sector and credible foreign companies. *Rendering consultancy and support services to [[Foreign Direct Investment in Iran|foreign investors]]. *[[Privatization in Iran|Privatization of the existing subsidiaries]]. *[[Industry of Iran|Industrial Investment]] *Management Development *[[Automotive industry in Iran|Automotive Industry]] *Industrial Equipment Machinery *[[Industry of Iran#Naval industry|Marine Industry]] *[[Iranian railway industry|Railway Industry]] *[[Industry of Iran#Electronics and computer industry|Hi-Tech Industries Development]] *[[Construction in Iran|General Contracting]] *[[Healthcare in Iran|Health care]] *[[Banking in Iran|Banking]] ==Privatization== {{See also|Privatization in Iran}} IDRO had privatized 140 of its companies worth about 2,000 billion rials ($200 million) in the past. The organization will offer shares of 150 industrial units to private investors by March 2010. In 2009, 290 companies were under the control of the IDRO.{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=99914§ionid=351020102 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402082947/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=99914§ionid=351020102 |archivedate=2012-04-02 |df= }} ===Subsidiaries=== {{See also|List of Iranian companies}} This is a list of IDRO's main subsidiaries (as of 2008): {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! revision.text:
{{Infobox comics character| |image=Machinesmith.jpg |image_size=250 |caption=Machinesmith.
Art by [[Paco Medina]]. |character_name=Machinesmith |real_name=Samuel "Starr" Saxon |publisher=[[Marvel Comics]] |debut=''[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]]'' #49 (February 1969; as Starr Saxon)
''Daredevil'' #54 (July 1969; as Mister Fear)
''Marvel Two-in-One'' #47 (January 1979; as Machinesmith) |creators=[[Stan Lee]] (writer)
[[Gene Colan]] (artist) |alliances=[[Masters of Evil]]
[[Skeleton Crew (comics)|Skeleton Crew]] |aliases=[[Mister Fear]] |powers=Scientific and robotic genius
Robotic Suits
Ability to transfer mind into other machines }} '''Machinesmith''' ('''Samuel "Starr" Saxon''') is a fictional [[supervillain]] appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]]. He specializes in [[robot]]ics, and is able to make convincing robotic [[Doppelgänger|doubles]] of other superhumans. His own [[mind]] was ultimately transferred to a robotic body. ==Publication history== The character first appeared in ''[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]]'' #49 (February 1969), and briefly appeared as a character to have used the [[Mister Fear]] identity shortly thereafter in ''Daredevil'' #54 (July 1969). The character first appeared as Machinesmith in ''Marvel Two-in-One'' #47 (January 1979). His robotic features looked nothing like his human ones, and it was not established until later in ''Captain America'' #249 (September 1980) that Machinesmith and Starr Saxon are the same character. [[Barry Windsor-Smith]] has stated that back the character was supposed to be presented as gay in ''Daredevil'' #50; however, the early art was not good enough to get the point across.{{Citation | last = Conroy | first = Mike | year = 2004 | title = 500 Comic Book Villains | publisher = Barron's | isbn = 0-7641-2908-2 }} Other issues have since revealed the character's sexuality more directly, such as ''Captain America'' #368 and ''Iron Man'' #320. ==Fictional character biography== Starr Saxon was born in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], but his family was living in [[Queens|Queens, New York]] by his teenage years. At 14 years old, he discovered an abandoned [[Doombot]] in a NYC subway tunnel, and snuck the robot home piece by piece to deconstruct to learn robotics.''Captain America'' #368 His original efforts saw to his use of robotics and engineering abilities to be a professional criminal robot maker and construct a variety of androids to be used as assassins for hire/personal gain. At some point during this period, he constructs a facsimile of [[Magneto (comics)|Magneto]] and a variety of [[The Demi Men|robotic "mutant" drones]] who went on to battle the [[X-Men]]. Magneto's robot appears several times over the years, believing itself to be the true Magneto until being destroyed by a [[Sentinel (comics)|Sentinel]]. As of this writing, his employer(s) for the robot's creation is unrevealed. In his first actual appearance, Saxon is hired by Biggie Benson to kill [[Daredevil (Marvel Comics character)|Daredevil]]. Saxon dispatches a powerful android to do so, and to commit a series of crimes in New York. He discovers Daredevil's secret identity, and kidnaps [[Karen Page]] (Daredevil's girlfriend). He blackmails Daredevil into allowing him to escape.''Daredevil'' #49-52 Deciding to confront Daredevil directly, Saxon murders [[Mister Fear|Zoltan Drago]] and steals the man's costume and weaponry. As "'''[[Mister Fear]]'''", he challenges Daredevil to a public duel in New York City. He rigs Daredevil's billy club to release fear-gas pellets, and begins a crime spree. However, Saxon battles Daredevil and loses, breaking his neck in a fall from a flying hovercraft platform.''Daredevil'' #54-55 Saxon's robots find his dying body and transfer his brain patterns and consciousness into a computer, from which he could control a variety of android bodies. Now calling himself the "Machinesmith", he is hired by the [[Corporation (comics)|Corporation]] agent known as the Carnation to defeat the [[Fantastic Four]]. He dispatches his robots to subdue the [[Thing (comics)|Thing]] to be brainwashed into destroying the Fantastic Four. The Thing encounters [[Jack of Hearts]] instead and is defeated and Machinesmith is then revealed to be a robot.''Marvel Two-in-One'' #47-48 When [[Captain America]] and [[Nick Fury]] have an encounter with [[Baron Strucker]], Captain America defeats Strucker who is revealed to be a robot, controlled remotely by Machinesmith who plots to destroy Captain America. He comes to despise his artificial life, but his programming prevents him from committing suicide. Machinesmith sends the [[Dragon Man]] to kill Captain America but the attempt is unsuccessful.''Captain America'' #247-249 Machinesmith is hired into the [[Red Skull]]'s exclusive employ, for whom he served as his primary scientist/machinist and member of the [[Skeleton Crew (comics)|Skeleton Crew]].''Captain America'' #368, flashback On several occasions, Machinesmith undertakes various the Red Skull's field missions, usually confronting Captain America. As per the Red Skull's orders, he sets mechanisms in [[S.H.I.E.L.D.]] Central against Captain America and Fury.''Captain America'' #351 As per the Red Skull's orders, he next activates the [[Sleeper (Marvel Comics)|Sleeper]] robot, and attempts to liberate the other robots impounded on [[Hydro-Base|Avengers Island]].''Captain America'' #354 He then assists [[Mother Night (comics)|Mother Night]] in an attempt to bug the [[Avengers Mansion|Avengers headquarters]], and he battles and overpowers the [[Vision (Marvel Comics)|Vision]].''Avengers'' #324-325 Alongside the Skeleton Crew, he later battles the [[Schutz-Heiliggruppe]].''Captain America'' #390-391 A portion of the Machinesmith's consciousness is eventually captured (assumed to be Saxon's entire consciousness), and enslaved by [[Iron Man|Tony Stark]] under [[Kang the Conqueror]]'s thrall.{{issue|date=March 2013}} Machinesmith later claims to have easily recovered the lost fragment which he re-assimilated.{{issue|date=March 2013}} When the Red Skull is blasted apart by Kubekult's [[Cosmic Cube]] destruction, Machinesmith enacts a series of protocols dictated by the Red Skull to kill Captain America and plunge the world into nuclear holocaust. Machinesmith is defeated.{{issue|date=March 2013}} Later, Machinesmith is employed by the [[Crimson Cowl (Justine Hammer)|Crimson Cowl]]'s [[Masters of Evil]].{{issue|date=March 2013}} After the team's defeat by the [[Thunderbolts (comics)|Thunderbolts]], Machinesmith has since lain low.{{issue|date=March 2013}} He later resurfaces and appears battling the [[New Warriors]].''New Warriors'' (vol. 4) #11 Machinesmith later appears in [[Madripoor]], having captured Captain America and deactivated the Super Soldier Serum in his foe's body. It was Machinesmith's intent to reverse-engineer the Super Soldier Serum to sell to various military officials. Captain America is able to regain the enhanced physique and defeats Machinesmith, trapping his consciousness inside a robotic body that he could not wirelessly transfer himself out of. At the end of the issue, Machinesmith was revealed to be an expendable pawn of the mysterious [[Shadow Council]].''Steve Rogers: Super-Soldier'' #2-4 But Machinesmith is resurrected a year later by [[Sharon Carter]] to discover how Captain America was consistently reverting to a weaker form, bargaining for his freedom. Machinesmith confessed to having been in league with Captain America's old comrade Codename: Bravo and revealed that Captain America was infected with nanotechnology that mimicked red blood cells. Unbeknownst to Machinesmith, Carter had infected him with a virus that wiped away his memories eliminating him as a threat.''Captain America'' (vol. 6) #8-10 Machinesmith is later [[parole]]d after helping the U.S. government hack into [[Latveria]]'s computer network. He moves to Miami and gets a menial job performing at children's birthday parties, before he is asked by [[Grizzly (comics)|Grizzly]] to help [[Ant-Man (Scott Lang)|Scott Lang]] with [[Cassandra Lang|Cassie Lang]]'s rescue from [[Cross Technological Enterprises]]. Machinesmith agrees on the condition that Lang gets him a job at Ant-Man Security Solutions as stable employment will help keep his [[parole officer]] off his back.''Ant-Man'' Vol. 2 #4 As part of the ''[[All-New, All-Different Marvel]]'' event, Machinesmith is temporarily hired by [[Augustine Cross]] to hack into the Power Broker Inc. database so that the Cross family could steal its algorithm to be used to create a Hench App knock-off called "Lackey" since [[Darren Cross]] refused to invest with [[Power Broker]].''Astonishing Ant-Man'' #2 During the ''[[Secret Empire (comics)|Secret Empire]]'' storyline, Machinesmith and Grizzly join up with the Army of Evil during Hydra's rise to power.''Secret Empire: Brave New World'' #1 ==Powers and equipment== Starr Saxon originally had a genius intellect, but no superhuman powers. He is one of the most gifted robot designers in the world, and has vast experience in cybernetic and bionics. After breaking his neck, his consciousness began to occupy a robot duplicate of himself, programmed with his complete brain patterns, and capable of self-motivated, creative activity. His robotic materials, design and construction provided him with a number of superhuman capacities, including superhuman strength, speed, stamina, durability, agility and reflexes. Machinesmith exists as a living, cybernetic-system program (artificial consciousness), which is equipped to transmit its program along an infrared laser beam into virtually any electronics system at will; thus he can transfer from one robotic body to another within .25 seconds. Machinesmith can even place his personal program (personality) into multiple bodies at the same time, though the number of complex motions he can make his automata perform simultaneously is limited. His physical properties vary in accordance with the robot form he is inside. Certain robots possess superhuman capacities such as telescoping arms and legs, explosive launchers, special infrared or telescopic eyes. He has yet to inhabit a robot body greatly superior to a standard human-mimicking robot's capacity.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} If an electronics system shuts down before he has a chance to project out of it, he can be trapped inside of it. Machinesmith is a genius at creating complex behavioral programs and bionic systems. Machinesmith has also created a vast arsenal of weaponry, defense systems, and surveillance devices, whose specifications are constantly upgraded. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Marvunapp|http://www.marvunapp.com/Appendix5/machinesmith.htm|Machinesmith}} * [http://www.marvel.com/universe/Machinesmith Machinesmith] at Marvel.com * [http://www.marveldirectory.com/individuals/m/machinesmith.htm Machinesmith at MarvelDirectory.com] * [http://www.gayleague.com/wordpress/2010/07/05/machinesmith/ Gay League profile] {{Captain America}} {{Daredevil}} {{New Warriors}} [[Category:Characters created by Gene Colan]] [[Category:Characters created by Stan Lee]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1969]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Tennessee]] [[Category:Fictional cyborgs]] [[Category:Fictional gay males]] [[Category:Fictional roboticists]] [[Category:Fictional shapeshifters]] [[Category:LGBT supervillains]] [[Category:Marvel Comics characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Marvel Comics robots]] [[Category:Marvel Comics supervillains]]

{{One source|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Marie Thérèse Félicité | full name = Maria Teresa Felicitas d'Este | image = MariaTheresiaFéliciavanModena.jpg | title = [[Duchess of Penthièvre]] | caption = 1750 portrait at [[Château d'Eu|Eu]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1726|10|6|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Ducal Palace of Modena|Ducal Palace]], [[Modena]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1754|4|30|1726|10|6||df=y}} | death_place = [[Château de Rambouillet]], [[France]] | spouse = [[Louis Jean Marie de Bourbon, Duke of Penthièvre]] | father = [[Francesco III d'Este, Duke of Modena]] | mother = [[Charlotte Aglaé d'Orléans]] | issue = [[Louis Alexandre, Prince of Lamballe]]
[[Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon, Duchess of Orléans|Marie Adélaide, Duchess of Orléans]] | burial_place = [[Chapelle royale de Dreux]] | religion = [[Roman Catholicism]] }} '''Maria Teresa Felicitas d'Este''' (October 6, 1726 – April 30, 1754) was born a princess of [[Modena]] and was by marriage the Duchess of Penthièvre. She was the mother-in-law of [[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Philippe Égalité]] and thus grandmother to the future [[Louis-Philippe of France]]. ==Life== Born in [[Emilia-Romagna]][https://books.google.com/books?id=2oEBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA278&lpg=PA278&dq=S.A.S+madame+la+duchesse+d'orl%C3%A9ans&source=web&ots=daOoMcrbZ5&sig=ahRyv5hu3Z2xIdP_yj-b5QA7ssA&hl=fr&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=6&ct=result#PPA3,M1 ''Journal de la vie de S.A.S. madame la Dsse. d'Orléans, douairière''] in [[Modena]], she was the daughter of [[Francesco III d'Este|Francesco III, Duke of Modena]] and his wife, the French princess [[Charlotte Aglaé d'Orléans]]. One of nine children, she was the first daughter of the family but her mother eventually returned to France to live. ==Marriage== Penthièvre was Maria Teresa's mother's first cousin. Charlotte Aglaé's mother was the sister of the duke's father, Louis-Alexandre Count of Toulouse. According to some contemporaries, the marriage between the duke and his wife was reportedly a happy one, to which numerous children were born. *[[Louis Marie, Duke of Rambouillet|Louis Marie de Bourbon]] (1746-1749); *[[Louis Alexandre, Prince of Lamballe]] (1747-1768); *[[Jean Marie, Duke of Châteauvillain|Jean Marie de Bourbon]] (1748-1755), ''duc de Châteauvillain''; *[[Vincent de Bourbon, Count of Guingamp|Vincent de Bourbon]] (1750-1752); *Marie Louise de Bourbon (1751-1753); *[[Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon, Duchess of Orléans|Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon]] (1753-1821); *Louis Marie Félicité de Bourbon (1754), died at birth. ==Descendants== Marie Thérèse died at the [[Château de Rambouillet]] after giving birth to Louis Marie Félicité de Bourbon, who died soon afterwards. Only two of the Penthièvre children survived into adulthood: * [[Louis-Alexandre de Bourbon, prince de Lamballe|Louis-Alexandre de Bourbon]], her second but only surviving son, married [[Princess Marie Louise of Savoy]], who after his death became the favourite of the future Queen [[Marie Antoinette]]. * [[Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon-Penthièvre]], her youngest and only surviving daughter, wed [[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans]], while he was still known as the [[Duke of Chartres]]. ==Gallery== File:Modène, François-Marie III de.jpg|[[Francesco III d'Este|Francesco III d'Este, Duke of Modena]] File:Charlotte Aglaé d'Orléans depicted as the goddess Hébé attributed to Pierre Gobert .jpg|[[Charlotte Aglaé of Orléans]] File:The Family of the Duke of Penthièvre.jpg|Maria Teresa's family; The [[Louis Jean Marie de Bourbon, duc de Penthièvre|Duke of Penthièvre]]; [[Louis-Alexandre de Bourbon, prince de Lamballe|Prince of Lamballe]]; [[Marie-Louise, princesse de Lamballe|Princess of Lamballe]]; ''[[Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon|Mademoiselle de Penthièvre]]'' next to the [[Marie Victoire de Noailles|Countess of Toulouse]] File:Rambouillet château3 dessin.jpg|The [[Château de Rambouillet]] File:Arms of Maria Teresa Felicitas d'Este as Duchess of Penthièvre.png|Arms ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |ref={{cite book|title=Genealogie ascendante jusqu'au quatrieme degre inclusivement de tous les Rois et Princes de maisons souveraines de l'Europe actuellement vivans| trans-title=Genealogy up to the fourth degree inclusive of all the Kings and Princes of sovereign houses of Europe currently living |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=AINPAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA86|year=1768|publisher=Frederic Guillaume Birnstiel|location=Bourdeaux|language=fr|page=86}} |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. [[Image:Rollinat.jpg|thumb|Maurice Rollinat, 1846-1903]] '''Maurice Rollinat''' (December 29, 1846 in [[Châteauroux]], [[Indre]] – October 26, 1903 in [[Ivry-sur-Seine]]) was a French [[poet]].
==Early works== His father represented [[Indre]] in the National Assembly of 1848, and was a friend of [[George Sand]], whose influence is very marked in young Rollinat's first volume, ''Dans les brandes'' (1877), and to whom it was dedicated.
==Brief fame== After its publication, he abandoned [[Literary realism|realism]] and worked in a very different manner. He joined a literary circle that called themselves ''[[Les Hydropathes]]'', founded by [[Émile Goudeau]], an [[anti-clericalism|anti-clerical]] group with ties to the [[decadent]] literary movement. Under their influence wrote the poems that made his reputation. In ''Les Névroses'', with the sub-title ''Les Âmes, Les Luxures, Les Refuges, Les Spectres, Les Ténèbres'', he showed himself as a disciple of [[Charles Baudelaire]]. He constantly returns in these poems to the physical horrors of death, and is obsessed by unpleasant images. Less outre in sentiment are ''L'Abîme'' (1886), ''La Nature'', and a book of children's verse, ''Le Livre de la Nature'' (1893).
He was musician as well as poet, and set many of his songs to music. Several evenings a week, Rollinat would appear at the [[cabaret]] [[Le Chat Noir]], and there he would perform his poems with piano accompaniment. His gaunt and pale appearance made his portrait a favourite subject for a number of painters, and the startling subjects of his verses brought him short lived fame; at the height of his popularity he drew a number of celebrities to the cabaret to see him perform; among them were [[Leconte de Lisle]] and [[Oscar Wilde]]. Rollinat's friend [[Jules Barbey d'Aurevilly]] wrote that "Rollinat might be Baudelaire's superior in the sincerity and depth of his diabolism".
Rollinat married the actress [[Cécile Pouettre]]. He lost his reason in consequence of his wife's death from [[rabies]]; after several [[suicide]] attempts, he died in an [[insane asylum]] at Ivry-sur-Seine. He is buried in the Saint-Denis cemetery in Châteauroux.
On Rollinat's death, [[Auguste Rodin]] offered the [[Fresselines]] commune a [[bas-relief]] entitled "Poet and the Muse". This sculpture is on display on the wall of the village church at [[Crozant]].
==Publications== * 1877 : ''Dans les brandes'' * 1883 : ''Les Névroses'' * 1886 : ''L'Abîme'' * 1887 : ''Dix mélodies nouvelles'' * 1892 : ''La Nature'' * 1893 : ''Le Livre de la nature'' (anthology) * 1896 : ''Les Apparitions'' * 1898 : ''Ce que dit la Vie et ce que dit la Mort'' * 1899 : ''Paysages et paysans'' * 1903 : ''En errant, proses d'un solitaire''
===Posthumes===
* 1904 : ''Ruminations : proses d'un solitaire'' * 1911 : ''Les Bêtes''
===Contemporary editions=== * Œuvres (éditées par R. Miannay - 1977) - Lettres Modernes Minard : **I. Dans les brandes (1877) ** II. Les Névrôses (1883)
==References== *{{EB1911|wstitle=Rollinat, Maurice|volume=23|page=468}} * Régis Miannay, ''Maurice Rollinat, poète et musicien du fantastique'', Badel, 1981. * Hugues Lapaire, ''Rollinat, poète et musicien'', Mellotté, 1932. * Claire Le Guillou, ''Rollinat : ses amitiés artistiques'', Joca seria, 2004. * Association des amis de M. Rollinat, ''Actes du colloque 1996'' (The hundredth anniversary of the poet's birth), 2005.
==External links== {{wikisourcelang|fr|Maurice Rollinat}} {{Commonscat}} * [http://www.cave-a-poemes.org/page.php?id=70 Biography and several poems] {{fr icon}} * [http://www.anthologie.free.fr/anthologie/rollinat/rollinat.htm A selection of his verse] {{fr icon}} * {{IMSLP|id=Rollinat, Maurice}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Maurice Rollinat}} * {{Librivox author |id=8492}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: Mikayla Marie isn't part of the set.
revision.text:
The '''McCaughey septuplets''' (born November 19, 1997), are [[septuplets]] (seven offspring) born to Kenny and Bobbi McCaughey in [[Des Moines, Iowa]], United States. They are the world's first set of surviving septuplets.
Bobbi and Kenny McCaughey (pronounced "McCoy") had one daughter, Mikayla Marie, born January 3, 1996.<ref name="Mikayla birthdate">{{cite web|url=http://www.americanbaby.com/ab/CDA/featureDetail/0,1349,1323-1,00.html?s=4|title=Bobbi McCaughey's Weekly Journal|date=16 April 2003|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030416032145/http://www.americanbaby.com/ab/CDA/featureDetail/0,1349,1323-1,00.html?s=4|archivedate=16 April 2003|df=}}</ref> While under treatment with ovulation-stimulating [[urofollitropin|Metrodin]] for infertility,<ref name=great/> Bobbi became pregnant with seven babies. The McCaugheys, residents of the town of [[Carlisle, Iowa|Carlisle]], declined [[selective reduction]] to reduce the number of infants, saying that they would "put it in God's hands". The obstetricians primarily responsible for the medical care of the babies were Karen Drake and Paula Mahone.{{cn|date=April 2017}}
The septuplets, four boys and three girls, were born nine weeks prematurely in Des Moines on November 19, 1997.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.goodhousekeeping.com/life/news/a35592/mccaughey-septuplets-turn-18/|title=See The McCaughey Septuplets All Grown Up!|date=2015-11-18|newspaper=Good Housekeeping|access-date=2016-12-24}}</ref> They were born by [[Caesarean section]], all within six minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3080203/|title= Septuplets’ mom recalls ‘terror,’ joy|publisher=MSNBC|date=November 26, 1997|accessdate= April 18, 2017}}</ref> They were the world's first set of surviving septuplets.<ref name=today>{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/parents/worlds-first-set-surviving-septuplets-turn-18-see-mccaughey-family-t44381|title=World's first set of surviving septuplets to turn 18: See the McCaughey family on TODAY|first=Scott|last=Stump|date=September 16, 2015|accessdate=April 18, 2017|work=Today}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- !Baby order!!Sex!!Birth weight!!Name |- | style="background:#8ab8e6;"|1 || style="background:#8ab8e6;"| Boy || style="background:#8ab8e6;" | {{Convert|3|lb|4|oz|kg|abbr=on}} || style="background:#8ab8e6;"| Kenneth (Kenny) Robert |- | style="background:pink;"|2 || style="background:pink;"| Girl || style="background:pink;" | {{Convert|2|lb|11|oz|kg|abbr=on}} || style="background:pink;"| Alexis May |- | style="background:pink;"|3 || style="background:pink;"| Girl || style="background:pink;" | {{Convert|2|lb|10|oz|kg|abbr=on}} || style="background:pink;" |Natalie Sue |- | style="background:pink;"|4 || style="background:pink;"| Girl || style="background:pink;" | {{Convert|2|lb|5|oz|kg|abbr=on}} || style="background:pink;"| Kelsey Ann |- | style="background:#8ab8e6;"|5 || style="background:#8ab8e6;"| Boy || style="background:#8ab8e6;" | {{Convert|3|lb|3|oz|kg|abbr=on}} || style="background:#8ab8e6;"| Nathan Roy |- | style="background:#8ab8e6;"|6 || style="background:#8ab8e6;"| Boy || style="background:#8ab8e6;" | {{Convert|2|lb|14|oz|kg|abbr=on}} || style="background:#8ab8e6;"| Brandon James |- | style="background:#8ab8e6;"|7 || style="background:#8ab8e6;"| Boy || style="background:#8ab8e6;" | {{Convert|2|lb|15|oz|kg|abbr=on}} || style="background:#8ab8e6;"|Joel Steven |}
Two of the septuplets, Alexis (the oldest girl of the set) and Nathan (the 2nd oldest boy of the set), have [[cerebral palsy]]. Both used walkers to get around, and in November 2005 Nathan had spinal surgery in order to improve his walking abilities.<ref name=great>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/10867824/ |title=Eight is great for the McCaughey septuplets |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |date=January 15, 2006}}</ref>
==Public response== The birth attracted significant media attention, both positive and negative, including a feature in [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] in December 1997.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19971201,00.html |title=Kenny and Bobbi McCaughey |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=December 1, 1997}}</ref> "In the beginning, for every ten letters we would get that were happy for us, we'd get one letter accusing us of exploiting the kids and being selfish to waste the world's resources on a family this big," said Bobbi in a 2007 interview. "Our neighbors never gawked. Here in Carlisle they gave us privacy. But we had complete strangers come around to the back door, knock, and ask if they could hold a baby."<ref name="Baptist Bulletin">{{cite web|url=http://www.baptistbulletin.org/?p=749 |title=The McCaughey Family is Completely Normal |first=Kevin |last=Mungons |publisher=''Baptist Bulletin'' |date=November 2007}}</ref>
The McCaugheys were the recipients of many donations, including a 5500 ft² (511 m²) house, a van and diapers for the first two years, as well as nanny services, clothes, and even the State of Iowa offering full college scholarships to any [[state university]] in Iowa upon their maturity and graduation from high school, also by the [[Hannibal–LaGrange University]] in Missouri.{{cn|date=April 2017}} President [[Bill Clinton]] personally telephoned the McCaugheys to wish them his congratulations.<ref name=today/> The surviving [[Dionne quintuplets]]- Yvonne Dionne, Annette Allard, and Cecile Langlois- wrote a letter warning the parents to keep the septuplets out of the public eye and not allow them to fall into the same pitfalls as their parents did, but wished them the best of luck in raising them and their personal congratulations.<ref>[http://gosselinswithoutpity.blogspot.com/2008/07/open-letter-from-dionne-quintuplets.html "Open letter from the Dionne quintuplets"]. 1997.</ref>
By the time of the septuplets' tenth birthday in 2007, the family was declining most requests for interviews, other than annual stories with [[KCCI]] (the Des Moines [[CBS]] affiliate) and [[Ladies' Home Journal]]. Bobbi McCaughey has noted that the level of media attention does not necessarily mean they have granted many interviews, saying, "There was all kinds of stuff in the papers early on but they never actually interviewed us. Most of it is one paper quoting another."<ref name="Baptist Bulletin"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/22223331/ |title=After 10 years, new adventures for septuplets: The McCaughey family goes to Spain and the world's first surviving septuplets cope with life getting more complex |first=Ann |last=Curry |date=December 12, 2007 |work=Dateline stories <!-- NBC has followed the septuplets since birth-->}}</ref>
Bobbi and Kenny McCaughey occasionally speak at [[pro-life]] events and continue to oppose [[selective reduction]]. Bobbi has been quoted as saying, "Well, come to our house, and tell me which four I shouldn't have had!"{{cn|date=April 2017}} The family continues to attend a Baptist church in [[West Des Moines]] where Kenny serves as a deacon.<ref name="Baptist Bulletin"/> In 2010, [[TLC (TV network)|TLC]] made a documentary for the septuplets' thirteenth birthday that aired on December 28, 2010.
The septuplets graduated from high school in May 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kgw.com/news/nation-now/mccaughey-septuplets-graduate-high-school/210345425 |title=McCaughey septuplets graduate high school |first=Charly |last=Haley |work=The Des Moines Register |date= May 22, 2016}}</ref> Natalie, Kelsey, Nathan and Joel took up scholarships offered by private [[Hannibal-LaGrange University]] in [[Hannibal, Missouri]], Kenny and Alexis chose to stay in the Des Moines area and attend [[Des Moines Area Community College]], and Brandon enlisted in the [[United States Army]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/McCaughey-Septuplets-Start-College-Hannibal-LaGrange-University |title=4 of the McCaughey Septuplets Start College at Hannibal-LaGrange University |publisher=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date= August 28, 2016}}</ref> Brandon will be the first one to get married as he was engaged to Alana Hale and will wed in July 2018.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:McCaughey}} [[Category:1997 births]] [[Category:American children]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Multiple births]] [[Category:People from Des Moines, Iowa]]
